citations.desc: Institutional Animal Care and Use Committee (IACUC).
citations.narrative:
Five protocols reviewed describe a literature search for consideration of alternatives, but the search did not address all of
the painful/distressful procedures described in the study. Two protocols, 155F and 076F, describe a craniotomy and a
durotomy. 074K describes an intracranial surgery while 012F involves surgical insertion of probes and 595L includes a
retro-orbital intravenous injection. All 5 protocols identified the above procedures as causing pain or distress however the
consideration of alternatives did not address these procedures. The searches were therefore not adequate to determine
that alternatives were not available. In order to approve proposed activities, the IACUC shall determine that the principal
investigator has considered alternatives to procedures that may cause more than momentary or slight pain or distress to
the animals and has provided a written narrative description of the methods and sources used to determine that
alternatives were not available. Correct by 04/24/2024.

A review of IACUC approved protocol 595L found that it included housing guinea pigs at temperatures of 5°C (41°F) and
10°C (50°F) for seven days. Per the facility’s census, Guinea pigs were used on this protocol during the 2023 Fiscal Year,
however this exception to the AWA standards was not reported with the annual report submitted to USDA Animal Care.
To assure that the facility is adhering to the standards and regulations under the Act, a summary of all IACUC approved
exceptions must be attached to the annual report. Correct by submitting a revised FY 2023 annual report with a summary
of all exceptions including a brief explanation of the exceptions, as well as the species and number of animals affected.
Correct by February 26, 2024.

On 5/25/2023, a gerbil jumped out of his plastic enclosure as the lid was removed during a routine husbandry task. The
Gerbil landed on the floor, sustained multiple fractures of the left front leg as well as of the right hind limb, and was
subsequently euthanized. The husbandry task was not done in a manner to prevent injury to the gerbil. Handling of all
animals shall be done as expeditiously and carefully as possible in a manner that does not cause trauma, behavioral
stress, physical harm, or unnecessary discomfort. Corrective actions and preventative measures had been implemented
at the time of inspection.

citations.desc: Primary enclosures used to transport live animals.
citations.narrative:
On 11/12/2023, a pig sustained injuries to his snout during transport. Per the facility, the exact reason for the laceration
could not be determined but a sharp corner on a metal plate at the base of one of the walls was identified and theorized
as being the most likely cause. The interior of a transport primary enclosure must be free from any protrusions that could
be injurious to the live animals contained therein. Corrective actions and preventative measures had been implemented at
the time of inspection.
This inspection and exit interview were conducted with facility representatives.
n

narrative:
2.31(d)(1)(ii) 
   
Institutional Animal Care and Use Committee (IACUC). 
Five protocols reviewed describe a literature search for consideration of alternatives, but the search did not address all of 
the painful/distressful procedures described in the study. Two protocols, 155F and 076F, describe a craniotomy and a 
durotomy. 074K describes an intracranial surgery while 012F involves surgical insertion of probes and 595L includes a 
retro-orbital intravenous injection. All 5 protocols identified the above procedures as causing pain or distress however the 
consideration of alternatives did not address these procedures. The searches were therefore not adequate to determine 
that alternatives were not available. In order to approve proposed activities, the IACUC shall determine that the principal 
investigator has considered alternatives to procedures that may cause more than momentary or slight pain or distress to 
the animals and has provided a written narrative description of the methods and sources used to determine that 
alternatives were not available. Correct by 04/24/2024. 
2.36(b)(3) 
   
Annual report. 
A review of IACUC approved protocol 595L found that it included housing guinea pigs at temperatures of 5°C (41°F) and 
10°C (50°F) for seven days. Per the facility’s census, Guinea pigs were used on this protocol during the 2023 Fiscal Year, 
however this exception to the AWA standards was not reported with the annual report submitted to USDA Animal Care. 
To assure that the facility is adhering to the standards and regulations under the Act, a summary of all IACUC approved 
exceptions must be attached to the annual report. Correct by submitting a revised FY 2023 annual report with a summary 
of all exceptions including a brief explanation of the exceptions, as well as the species and number of animals affected. 
Correct by February 26, 2024. 
2.131(b)  Critical
   
Handling of animals 
On 5/25/2023, a gerbil jumped out of his plastic enclosure as the lid was removed during a routine husbandry task. The 
Gerbil landed on the floor, sustained multiple fractures of the left front leg as well as of the right hind limb, and was 
subsequently euthanized. The husbandry task was not done in a manner to prevent injury to the gerbil. Handling of all 
animals shall be done as expeditiously and carefully as possible in a manner that does not cause trauma, behavioral

stress, physical harm, or unnecessary discomfort. Corrective actions and preventative measures had been implemented 
at the time of inspection. 
3.137(a)(2) 
   
Primary enclosures used to transport live animals. 
On 11/12/2023, a pig sustained injuries to his snout during transport. Per the facility, the exact reason for the laceration 
could not be determined but a sharp corner on a metal plate at the base of one of the walls was identified and theorized 
as being the most likely cause. The interior of a transport primary enclosure must be free from any protrusions that could 
be injurious to the live animals contained therein. Corrective actions and preventative measures had been implemented at 
the time of inspection. 
 
This inspection and exit interview were conducted with facility representatives.
